Some of the future plans for <monospace>cluster-lensing</monospace> include adding support for different density profiles. Currently, only the NFW model is provided, and alternative mass density models would make the package more complete and useful. The first priority will be inclusion of the Einasto profile (Einasto <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaa400dbib10">1965</xref>), and later possibilities may include the generalized NFW (Zhao <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaa400dbib50">1996</xref>). The fundamental unit of ray-tracing is a single “ray”, which can be interpreted as a wave package of many photons or as a single photon. Most X-ray detectors are photon counting; thus, it is convenient to identify each ray with a single photon in this case. MARXS generates a list of photons, which is stored in an <monospace>astropy.table.Table</monospace> object (Astropy Collaboration et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaa943bbib1">2013</xref>). We present <monospace>astroplan</monospace>—an open source, open development, Astropy affiliated package for ground-based observation planning and scheduling in Python. <monospace>astroplan</monospace> is designed to provide efficient access to common observational quantities such as celestial rise, set, and meridian transit times and simple transformations from sky coordinates to altitude-azimuth coordinates without requiring a detailed understanding of <monospace>astropy</monospace>’s implemen

The Astropy Project is a community effort to develop a common core package for astronomy in Python and to foster an ecosystem of interoperable astronomy packages. The <monospace>astropy</monospace> core package contains all of the machinery necessary for computing whether or not a given object is observable from a location on the Earth at specified times. It defines an object-oriented framework for specifying times and coordinates on the sky and Earth. In this paper, we assume that the reader ha

The Astropy Project is a community effort to develop a common core package for astronomy in Python and to foster an ecosystem of interoperable astronomy packages. The <monospace>astropy</monospace> core package contains all of the machinery necessary for computing whether or not a given object is observable from a location on the Earth at specified times. It defines an object-oriented framework for specifying times and coordinates on the sky and Earth. In this paper, we assume that the reader ha

There are several practical algorithms useful for observation planning that are not included in <monospace>astropy</monospace>. Some questions that users may seek to answer using <monospace>astropy</monospace> would require substantial effort, such as: “is this star currently above 30° altitude from the Apache Point Observatory?” or “what time is astronomical twilight this evening on MaunaKea?”

There are several practical algorithms useful for observation planning that are not included in <monospace>astropy</monospace>. Some questions that users may seek to answer using <monospace>astropy</monospace> would require substantial effort, such as: “is this star currently above 30° altitude from the Apache Point Observatory?” or “what time is astronomical twilight this evening on MaunaKea?”

<monospace>astroplan</monospace> is an Astropy affiliated package for ground-based observation planning and scheduling, which provides functionality for answering these questions. It is a pure-Python package that provides an efficient application programming interface (API) for quick access to common observational calculations, while using the full accuracy and precision of <monospace>astropy</monospace> under-the-hood to handle the sky and time coordinate transformations.

The most similar existing Python software that can be used to plan observations is <monospace>pyephem</monospace> (Rhodes <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaaa47ebib10">2011</xref>). <monospace>astroplan</monospace> is different from <monospace>pyephem</monospace> in a few fundamental ways. <monospace>astroplan</monospace> provides support for computing the positions of the Sun, Moon, stars, and major planets. It uses <monospace>astropy</monospace>’s modern and more accurate IAU2000/2006 methods and

The most similar existing Python software that can be used to plan observations is <monospace>pyephem</monospace> (Rhodes <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaaa47ebib10">2011</xref>). <monospace>astroplan</monospace> is different from <monospace>pyephem</monospace> in a few fundamental ways. <monospace>astroplan</monospace> provides support for computing the positions of the Sun, Moon, stars, and major planets. It uses <monospace>astropy</monospace>’s modern and more accurate IAU2000/2006 methods and
An observer can be located anywhere on the Earth with use of <monospace>astropy</monospace>’s <monospace>EarthLocation</monospace> object.

The <monospace>from</monospace>_<monospace>name</monospace> class method uses tools from <monospace>astropy.coordinates</monospace> to query Simbad, NED, and VizieR for target coordinates by name through the Sesame Name Resolver (Schaaff <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaaa47ebib11">2004</xref>). Non-fixed targets apart from the Sun and Moon are not implemented in astroplan at the time of writing, and community contributions for supporting minor bodies are welcome.

We chose to compute rise and set times with a grid-search to maximize accuracy, rather than speed. In particular, we sought to preserve the <monospace>astropy</monospace> altitude-azimuth coordinate transformation, which accounts for atmospheric refraction.
Times can be defined in a variety of scales using <monospace>astropy Time</monospace> objects, including UTC, TAI, TCB, TCG, TDB, TT, UT1.

The sky coordinates of the major solar system bodies are computed using the <monospace>jplephem</monospace> package, which provides an API for querying JPL’s Satellite Planet Kernel files. The methods for querying the positions of solar system bodies were originally developed for <monospace>astroplan</monospace>, and have since been moved into the <monospace>astropy.coordinates</monospace> package.

An airmass plot and a sky chart for observing Sirius and Rigel from Apache Point Observatory, made with the <monospace>astroplan.plots</monospace> methods <monospace>plot</monospace>_<monospace>airmass</monospace> and <monospace>plot</monospace>_<monospace>sky</monospace>. The underlying altitude/azimuth calculation powered by <monospace>astropy.coordinates</monospace> includes atmospheric refraction.

To investigate the ionization structure of the NLR, we measure both the size and the [O iii]λ5007 luminosity of the region. To determine the radius (in parsecs) of the NLR, we use half the Akaike width, defined in Section 2.3. We then convert to a physical distance using the Python astropy.cosmology utility.

Introduction

A refreshing recent development in astronomy research and higher education is the advent of computational tools for commonplace platforms of the type that students are likely to own. This has been enabled by the power and capacity of consumer devices, which now exceed those of institutional workstations of previous decades. In this section, we investigate the outflow morphology and velocity distribution inferred from emission in several observational tracers. In order to generate synthetic emission maps, we post-process the simulations at selected intervals with radmc-3d5

http://www.ita.uni-heidelberg.de/dullemond/software/radmc-3d/

We post-process the simulations with <sc>radmc-3d</sc> to produce synthetic molecular line emission maps in <sup>12</sup>CO, <sup>13</sup>CO, and C<sup>18</sup>O. The emission morphologies of the simulated outflow cavities appear similar to observed outflows. The line width is anti-correlated with the tracer critical density, and as expected, <sup>12</sup>CO is a better probe of the outflow gas. The goal of this paper is to study the distribution of a large variety of species and understand the correlations between them. We model a Milky Way-like molecular cloud using the magnetohydrodynamic code, <sc>orion</sc>. We then post processes these results with the 3D astrochemistry code, <sc>3d-pdr</sc> (Bisbas et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apj506796r7">2012</xref>), using an extended chemical network to obtain the abundances of over 200 different species. Optical depth indicates the degree of transparency. Tracers that are optically thin, such as NH<sub>3</sub>, have emission that reflects the underlying density structure more accurately. Figure <xref ref-type="fig" rid="apj506796f7">7</xref> shows the optical depth of each line transition at the line center calculated by <sc>radmc-3d</sc>. The figure shows that C, CO, CN, and C+ all have high optical depths. This is a result of having a lower critical density with a relatively high abundance. Th

Line center optical depths calculated by <sc>radmc-3d</sc>. The HCN and CO density profiles in this plot are treated with a crude dust treatment described in the <xref ref-type="sec" rid="apj506796app1">Appendix</xref>. The HCN optical depth is divided by a factor of three to approximate the addition of the fine structure component to the transition.

The best way to compare observations and simulations is to directly compare similar data products. The production of synthetic observations of simulated data sets enables such a comparison by modeling the way light travels through space and into telescopes. Astrophysics has a rich history in producing mock spectra in many contexts, including stars (e.g., Kurucz <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apjaa7e2dbib47">1979</xref>), the Sun (e.g., Husser et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apjaa7e2dbib39">2013</x

We note that in our observations the N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>&plus;</sup> does not seem to be affected by freeze-out or outflow motions, unlike the more optically thick tracers in our sample, such as HCO<sup>&plus;</sup> and CS. Given that our simulation does not include outflow motions or freeze-out chemistry, we only use the N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>&plus;</sup> to compare with the observations. We produce N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>&plus;</sup> (1–0) maps for several different views at times ∼0.

Trimmed_XML_tag1_content: The chemical species which we will consider in this paper have emission lines with high critical densities and as such are typically not in local thermal equilibrium (LTE). Consequently, a non-LTE approach must be used for the line transfer. We use the large velocity gradient (LVG) approximation (Sobolev <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apj425281r57">1957</xref>) which uses local velocity gradients to define photon escape probabilities. Trimmed_XML_tag2_content:
RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL CALCULATIONS

Various dust species in the envelopes around OH/IR stars may have multiple components rather than a single component. It is difficult to reproduce the observed SEDs using a single component dust shell model (e.g., CSDUST3 code developed by Egan et al. 1988 and DUSTY code developed by Ivezić & Elitzur 1997).

It is difficult to reproduce the observed SEDs using a single component dust shell model (e.g., CSDUST3 code developed by Egan et al. 1988 and DUSTY code developed by Ivezić & Elitzur 1997).

(<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apj452669r24">2011a</xref>) with our observational interferometric data we selected two regions with low and high fragmentation as seen with the PdBI-A. For the low-fragmentation case we selected I22198 to be compared to the μ = 2 (highly magnetized) simulated maps, while for the high-fragmentation case we selected A5142 to be compared to the μ = 130 (weakly magnetized) simulated maps.

SUMMARY

We have imaged nine Class II disks in Taurus in the 1.3 mm continuum and the J = 2–1 lines of CO, 13CO, and C18O with the SMA. CO is detected in all disks, 13CO in seven, and C18O only in one. To interpret the data, we created an azimuthally symmetric model of a hydrostatically supported gas disk with a basic parameterization of the CO chemistry incorporating dissociation at a fixed

Trimmed_XML_tag2_content:
ASTROPHYSICAL IMPLICATIONS

The porosity is a crucial parameter that defines the efficiency of adsorption, diffusion, and reaction, as well as the entrapment capacities of molecules in interstellar ices. By providing large effective surface areas, pores have important consequences for the chemistry driven by surface processes. The presence of pores, as well as the evolution of the porosity during the different stages of star formation, are key to understanding

Description of the Model

We follow the methodology in Paper I but create a library of resolved images rather than a table of total line luminosities. The gas is assumed to be azimuthally symmetric, in hydrostatic equilibrium, and under Keplerian rotation. Trimmed_XML_tag2_content: We modeled the observations using RADMC-3D with customized code to include polarization from emission and absorption by aligned elongated dust grains. We use the radiative transfer code RADMC-3D (Dullemond et al. 2012) to determine the temperature in the disk. Trimmed_XML_tag1_content: We have for the first time derived synthetic images  including the heating produced by the shocks that high-mass planets cause in their parent disks.  During this work, the public version of the code RADMC-3D was modified to include  a general heating rate leading to emission from every cell.
Trimmed_XML_tag2_content:
Conclusions

We have for the first time derived synthetic images  including the heating produced by the shocks that high-mass planets cause in their parent disks.  During this work, the public version of the code RADMC-3D was modified to include  a general heating rate leading to emission from every cell.

We explore the observational signatures of this shock heating, using the hydrodynamical model of Paper II</

Overview

To explore possible origins for the 12CO emission substructure, we perform radiative transfer calculations based on several sets of parametric structure models. Given the complex details visible at high resolution, as well as the large computational cost of synthesizing the image cubes, our aim in this work is not to present an optimal model, but to provide guidance for which physical and chemical mechanisms would plausibly yield the key

Trimmed_XML_tag2_content:

While the fiducial model illustrates that substructure in the CO column density profile is compatible with the observed 12CO emission, it does not by itself demonstrate that substructures are necessary to create the observed emission features. The models discussed above contain all of the relevant features of protoplanetary disks but are nonetheless extremely simple models, particularly regarding the vertical temperature profile. A more realistic temperature profile for the outer regions of an externally illuminated disk would have a colder midplane and hotter disk surface, assuming that viscous heating is negligible (see Dullemond et al.

However, we can use ray-tracing calculations to investigate the accuracy of the inferred gas temperature from the line emission. Structure and Emission

The models discussed above contain all of the relevant features of protoplanetary disks but are nonetheless extremely simple models, particularly regarding the vertical temperature profile. A more realistic temperature profile for the outer regions of an externally illuminated disk would have a colder midplane and hotter disk surface, assuming that viscous heating is negligible (see Dullemond et al.

Unlike other commonly used ray-tracing codes (for example, RADMC-3D), it does not use a gridded disk structure. Gridded models work by dividing the disk into radius, zenith, and azimuth bins, each with a separate density, temperature, and composition. INTRODUCTION

Gravitationally unstable (GI) disks are expected in the early phases of star formation, when the disk mass can still be an appreciable fraction of the stellar mass, during the Class 0/Class I stage. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS

We have reported a proof-of-concept study that combines high-resolution radiation-hydro simulations of GI disks with synthetic observations. Our study shows that ALMA can detect GI clumps on the scale of gas giants in the early stages of their collapse. This finding extends the results of Dipierro et al. (2014), who showed how even fairly complex spiral structure can be detected by

We analyzed a Class I YSO, GSS30-IRS1, observed with the Herschel/PACS, as a part of the DIGIT key program. We investigated its physical conditions based on the PACS observations by analysis of molecular and atomic lines and modeling the dust continuum emission using the 3D dust continuum radiative transfer code (RADMC-3D).

SUMMARY

We analyzed a Class I YSO, GSS30-IRS1, observed with the Herschel/PACS, as a part of the DIGIT key program. We investigated its physical conditions based on the PACS observations by analysis of molecular and atomic lines and modeling the dust continuum emission using the 3D dust continuum radiative transfer code (RADMC-3D).

SYNTHETIC DUST TRAP MODEL

We constructed a synthetic model of a protoplanetary disk with a dust trap to make predictions comparable to the ALMA and ATCA observations of HD 142527. This synthetic model matches the observed SED (see below) and is a perfected version of that which accounts for the scattered-light shadows (Marino et al. 2015) with a tilted inner disk. This model allows us to (1) assess if

As summarized in Figure <xref ref-type="fig" rid="apj520227f14">14</xref>, the basic features of the graybody diagnostics approximate those seen in the data. There is a mild extension of the optical depth map into the northern ansa, which could be emphasized with higher optical depths. The center of the dust trap coincides with a minimum in <italic>β</italic><sub><italic>S</italic></sub>.

Trimmed_XML_tag1_content: The Fragment Image Reconstruction Engine (FIRE) creates images from FSE, PKDGRAV, and FARGO output files, and also creates RADMC3D input files. FSE files provide the dust density information for maps and RADMC3D input, FARGO files provide gas density maps, and PKDGRAV files ensure alignment between different maps. Dust lifetime algorithms are applied to collision fragments.
Trimmed_XML_tag2_content:
Synthetic Observations

The Fragment Image Reconstruction Engine (FIRE) creates images from FSE, PKDGRAV, and FARGO output files, and also creates RADMC3D input files. FSE files provide the dust density information for maps and RADMC3D input, FARGO files provide gas density maps, and PKDGRAV files ensure alignment between different maps. Dust lifetime algorithms are applied to collision fragments.

The visibility of dust is directly related to its size

CONCLUSION

In this work we present results from four simulations (Table 1), each of which has had its second-generation dust modeled in three separate ways (Table 2). All simulations were integrated with the PKDGRAV code using the EDACM collision model. During these simulations each collision was recorded, and a modified version of the EDACM collision model was use

Expected CO Fluxes

Only 21 of the 55 continuum-detected sources in our sample were also detected in CO. The relatively low number of CO detections suggested that the CO is either heavily depleted relative to the dust or has a compact emitting area due to small disk sizes. In this section, we test the latter possibility. We used the results of our continuum modeling to predict the CO

Trimmed_XML_tag1_content: We implemented our model in RADMC3D using spherical coordinates, with regular spacing for the azimuthal angle and logarithmic spacing in radius and colatitude (polar coordinate). Thus, the grid is naturally refined near the inner disk and the midplane. The radial grid is additionally refined as it approaches the inner wall of the outer disk (near 140 AU) to ensure a gradual transition from the optically thin gap to the optically thick outer disk. Keck/DEIMOS Data Reduction

The spectra were reduced using the IDL spec2d pipeline written for the DEEP2 galaxy survey (J. A. Newman et al. 2009, in preparation). Images were flat-fielded using an internal quartz lamp, and wavelength-calibrated using ArKrNeXe arc lamps. After sky subtraction, individual one-dimensional spectra were optimally extracted. Some sample extracted spectra are shown in Figure 2.

Trimmed_XML_tag1_content: To measure the spatial centroid of an emission component, first we center a 2 Å  (rest-frame) wide window on the emission. At each spatial position we then sum the flux, weighted by the inverse variance, over all wavelengths within the window. We use the spatial position where the summed flux is maximum as the center of a 10 pixel window (where 1 DEIMOS pixel spans 0&farcs;11) around the emission. The DEIMOS masks were processed using the software pipeline <monospace>spec2d</monospace> developed by the UCB members of the DEEP2 team. The pipeline performed a number of functions. Flat‐field exposures were used to rectify the curved spectra in the raw spectrogram into rectangular arrays by applying shifts in the spatial direction. Next, a one‐dimensional slit function correction and two‐dimensional flat‐field and fringing corrections were applied to each slitlet.

Spectroscopic calibration, extraction, classification, and redshift measurement of all BOSS galaxy spectra are carried out using the <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> software (see, e.g., Aihara et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="aj423377r1">2011</xref>), written originally for SDSS-I and recently updated to handle the data format and noise regime of BOSS. In selecting our analysis sample, we make the following cuts based upon the redshift pipeline output.<list list-type="ordered"><list-item><la

Our strategy for extracting velocity-dispersion information is to make use of the full velocity-dispersion likelihood function for each galaxy spectrum. To do this, we make use of the IDL routine <monospace>vdispfit</monospace> within the <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> product of spectroscopic analysis software. This software has been extensively tested in the SDSS-I, and has been upgraded for the analysis of BOSS data. Velocity dispersions measured with this software have been the basis for m

As described above, before being fit to the galaxy spectra, the stellar eigenspectra are shifted by the appropriate galaxy redshifts. If the redshifts have non-negligible errors, the corresponding offsets can introduce a bias into the measured velocity dispersion. Although the BOSS spectra provide redshifts with a precision well in excess of what is required for large-scale structure studies and absolute-magnitude determinations, their errors can be non-negligible on the scale of internal galaxy

The organization of this paper is as follows. Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="aj444842s2">2</xref> presents an overview of the spectroscopic data sample of BOSS DR9. Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="aj444842s3">3</xref> describes the classification and redshift pipeline algorithms and procedures, including the core redshifting algorithm (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="aj444842s3-1">3.1</xref>), special classification handling for the galaxy target samples (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid=

Schematic illustration of the <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> redshift measurement algorithm. The reduced χ<sup>2</sup> curve as a function of redshift (black curve) is determined from the best-fit linear combination of template basis spectra at each trial redshift value. The best redshift is defined by the location of the global minimum (green). Subsidiary minima separated by less than 1000 km s<sup>−1</sup> are not considered to be separate (pink). The implementation of the <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> redshift code is designed to meet the BOSS scientific requirements on redshift success rates, as discussed in the Introduction. The original SDSS-I/II code operated on spectra alone, without imposing classification or redshift priors based on photometric data or other targeting information. At the S/N typical of SDSS-I/II spectra, this technique proved highly successful, resulting in a redshift success rate better than 99&per

Emission-line parameters for the 31 transitions listed in Table <xref ref-type="table" rid="aj444842t5">5</xref> are computed for all spectra for which those lines fall into the observed BOSS wavelength range. Each line is modeled as a Gaussian, and the amplitudes, centroids, and widths of all lines are optimized non-linearly to obtain a minimum-χ<sup>2</sup> fit to the data. The background continuum spectrum is taken from the best-fit velocity-dispersion model (for galaxies), from the best-fit

These files are listed in Table <xref ref-type="table" rid="aj444842t6">6</xref>; together they contain all the parameters described in this paper. We have described the “1D” component of the <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> pipeline that provides automated redshift measurement and classification for the SDSS-III BOSS DR9 data set, which comprises 831,000 optical spectra. This software is substantially similar to the <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> redshift analysis code used for SDSS-I/II data, but has been upgraded with new templates and several new algorithms for application to the BOSS project, and has been presented in great detai

CONCLUSION

The data from the 2009–2010 and the 2010–2011 BOSS observing seasons are included in DR9. Observations followed a pace that was close to the survey projections; 236 unique plates were completed in first year compared with an expectation of 331. While this rate was about 30% behind the required rate to complete the survey, the slow start can largely be explained by the deeper exposures that were acquired. The S/N2 thresh

Future Improvements in Automated Data Reduction

The eBOSS spectroscopic pipeline will be based on the BOSS spectroscopic pipeline that was adapted from the original SDSS “idlspec2d” pipeline. It consists of two main parts: the “spectro2d” portion that extracts two-dimensional raw data into one-dimensional flux calibrated spectra; and the “spectro1d” portion that measures scalar quantities such as classifications and redshifts from those one-dimensional spec

Similarly, the MaNGA Data Reduction Pipeline (<sc>mangadrp</sc>; hereafter the DRP) is also divided into two components. Like the <sc>kungifu</sc> package (Bolton & Burles <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaa2d14bib14">2007</xref>), the two-dimensional (2D) stage of the DRP is based largely on the SDSS BOSS spectroscopic reduction pipeline <sc>idlspec2d</sc> (D. Schlegel et al. 2016, in preparation), and processes the raw CCD data to produce sky-subtracted, flux-calibrated spectra for each fiber. The

The 2D stage of the MaNGA DRP is largely derived from the BOSS idlspec2d pipeline (see, e.g., Dawson et al. 2013, Schlegel et al., in preparation)28

The idlspec2d software has also been used for the DEEP2 survey; see Newman et al. (2013).

 that has been modified
The <sc>idlspec2d</sc> software has also been used for the DEEP2 survey; see Newman et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaa2d14bib51">2013</xref>).

As discussed in previous section, the 2D stage of the MaNGA DRP (i.e., raw data through flux calibrated individual exposures) is derived in large part from the <sc>idlspec2d</sc> software that has been widely used in one form or another from the original SDSS spectroscopic survey (Abazajian et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaa2d14bib1">2003</xref>), to the BOSS and eBOSS surveys (Dawson et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaa2d14bib25">2013</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaa2d14bib24">2016

Spectral Pre-processing (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s4-1">4.1</xref>): <sc>mangadrp</sc> and <sc>idlspec2d</sc> use nearly identical algorithms, except that for MaNGA the cosmic-ray identification routine is run twice to flag additional features missed the first time.

Spatial Fiber Tracing (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s4-2-1">4.2.1</xref>): The <sc>mangadrp</sc> fiber tracing code is substantially different from that used by <sc>idlspec2d</sc>. For BOSS, the initial fiber locations in the starting row were determined by locating peaks and determining which block of fibers a given peak must belong to (and which fibers were missing) based on the known (and constant) number of fibers in each v-groove block. This method proved unreliable for MaNGA g

Scattered Light (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s4-2-3">4.2.3</xref>): The bspline scattered light routine implemented in <sc>mangadrp</sc> for bright-time data and flat-fields is entirely new compared to <sc>idlspec2d</sc>.

Spectral Extraction (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s4-2-2">4.2.2</xref>): The spectral extraction technique used by <sc>mangadrp</sc> is similar to that of <sc>idlspec2d</sc>. However, MaNGA uses the C-based implementation of the extraction used by the original SDSS-I survey (which extracts an entire detector row at a time) while BOSS and eBOSS use an IDL-based implementation that operates on a given v-groove block of fibers at a time. We found the latter to be undesirable for MaNGA
Fiber Flat-field (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s4-2-4">4.2.4</xref>): The fiber flat-field technique is nearly identical between <sc>mangadrp</sc> and <sc>idlspec2d</sc>.

Wavelength and LSF calibration (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s4-2-5">4.2.5</xref>): The initial wavelength solution and LSF estimate based on the arc-lamp calibration frames is nearly identical between <sc>mangadrp</sc> and <sc>idlspec2d</sc>, with the exception that MaNGA fits the derived LSF in a given v-groove block by a linear relation as a function of fiberid where BOSS uses a constant value for each block.

Science Frame extraction (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s4-3">4.3</xref>): The science frame extraction process is largely similar between <sc>mangadrp</sc> and <sc>idlspec2d</sc>, with the exception that BOSS makes no correction to the derived arc-line LSF based on the skylines.

Sky subtraction (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s5">5</xref>): Although the general approach to sky subtraction is similar between <sc>mangadrp</sc> and <sc>idlspec2d</sc>, in the sense that both use basis splines to build a super-sampled sky model, the practical implementation differs substantially. This difference is largely due to the fundamental hardware differences between the two surveys; where BOSS has 1000 fibers (science plus sky and standard) distributed nearly randomly acro

Flux calibration (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s6">6</xref>): As discussed by Yan et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ajaa2d14bib72">2016a</xref>), flux calibration techniques differ substantially between <sc>mangadrp</sc> and <sc>idlspec2d</sc> since MaNGA and BOSS are attempting to solve different problems. While BOSS must correct for both system throughput losses and geometric fiber aperture losses, MaNGA must disentangle the two and correct only for system losses. Although the co

Wavelength rectification (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="ajaa2d14s7">7</xref>): The spline-based approach to the wavelength rectification is common between both <sc>mangadrp</sc> and <sc>idlspec2d</sc>, but MaNGA uses a smoothed inverse-variance weighting approach where BOSS used simple inverse variance weighting (this has since been updated to smoothed inverse variance for eBOSS). MaNGA also uses a slightly different breakpoint spacing, and evaluates the bspline fit on both a logarithmic and

Principal ComponentAnalysis

We are interested in average spectra; however, we chooseto go further and perform PCAs on each set of spectra. This isolates a setof eigenspectra ranked by the amount of the total variance in the input setthat each explains. PCA is useful for identifying variations in the spectrabeyond the mean, and we find that emission‐line components areisolated by this technique.

Proper sky subtraction is often a problem beyond 7000 Å because of strong airglow lines and fringing in the CCD. To calculate the volume of the survey from the entire observable redshift range of the DEIMOS masks is, however, an overestimate; sky emission features render spectral regions of the data essentially unusable, necessitating bright line fluxes in order to exceed the sky noise. It is also tempting at this point to make a correction for the angular area of the slit lost by placing a relatively large lower redshift object (the targeted galaxy) in the center of each slit. Since our search depended almost entirely on human detection of sources, accurately quantifying the completeness limit of the objects detected is more difficult than in searches that use automatic peak finding algorithms. The human eye, while being very good at discriminating between spurious and real detections and at finding irregularities in data (serendips in our case), is subject to a variety of effects which are difficult to quantify. Spectroscopic Observations

We carried out further spectroscopic observations with the Subaru FOCAS (Kashikawa et al. 2002) and the Keck II DEIMOS (Faber et al. 2003) over the last four years (2006–2010). This spectroscopic campaign is summarized in Table 1.

The DEIMOS observations were undertaken over a series of runs from 2004 March through 2008 April. Slit masks were designed with position angles (P.A.s) within ±30° of the measured P.A. in order to minimize tilt angle corrections in the reduction process. We used the 1200 l mm<sup>−1</sup> grating blazed at 7500 Å with 1″ slits (with exception of 7 galaxies observed with the 600 l mm<sup>−1</sup> grating blazed at 7500 Å). Keck/DEIMOS Observations

The MMT/Hectospec data for RXJ1720 were supplemented with spectra obtained at the Keck II telescope using DEIMOS. In MOS mode, DEIMOS utilizes a slitmask to collect spectra for ∼100 target objects positioned within a ∼16&farcm;7 × 5′ FOV. The <monospace>spec2d</monospace> software also computed the error spectrum from Poisson statistics of the raw frame. The errors were adjusted appropriately during flat fielding, and the one-dimensional error spectrum was extracted identically to the flux spectrum. We used the error spectra for estimation of uncertainties in radial velocities (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="apj427095s3">3</xref>) and metallicities (Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="apj427095s6">6</xref>).

DEIMOS Observations and Data Reduction

A total of 4267 sources were targeted for spectroscopic observations with the DEIMOS multi-slit spectrograph (Faber et al. 2003) on the Keck II telescope. Full details of the observations and data can be found in P. Capak et al. (2012, in preparation). A total of 42 separate slit masks were observed, each with on average 102 1″ slits per mask. Our photometric catalogs are complemented by an unprecedented amount of spectroscopic data for large-scale structures at high redshifts. These data were taken using the Deep Imaging Multi-Object Spectrograph (DEIMOS; Faber et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apj456280r20">2003</xref>) on the Keck II 10 m telescope, as described in Rumbaugh et al. Observations and Reduction

Spectroscopic observations were obtained on the nights of 2012 April 22–23 and September 16–17 using the DEIMOS spectrograph on the Keck II telescope (Faber et al. 2003). We used the 1200 lines mm−1 grating covering a wavelength region of 6400–9100 Å. This provided an FWHM resolution of ≈1.3 Å, equivalent to 50 km s−1 at the center of our wavelength range.

We reduced the raw images into one-dimensional spectra with the <monospace>spec2d</monospace> software (Cooper et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apj471494r8">2012</xref>) developed by the Deep Extragalactic Evolutionary Probe 2 team (DEEP2; Davis et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apj471494r9">2003</xref>; Newman et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apj471494r42a">2013</xref>). We estimated uncertainties on <italic>v<sub>r</sub></italic> by resampling the spectrum and repeating the cross-correlation. The <monospace>spec2d</monospace> reduction software produced an estimate of the noise in each pixel. We added Gaussian random noise to each spectrum based on this array. M. Lubin, & J. B. Oke 2004, in preparation). The survey was conducted using LRIS and the Deep Imaging Multi‐Object Spectrograph (DEIMOS; Faber et al. 2003) on the Keck 10 m tel

Slit masks were observed with the 1200 l mm<sup>−1</sup> grating with an FWHM resolution of ∼1.7 Å (68 km s<sup>−1</sup>) and a typical wavelength coverage of 6385–9015 Å. To calculate redshifts we used a cross‐correlation redshift IDL algorithm in the publicly available <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> package written by David Schlegel. This algorithm used our visually classified template to find a best‐fit redshift and its associated error. All masked‐out regions were ignored in the redshift determination. However, there were several ways in which the code was inadequate, especially in light of the stellar focus of the SEGUE project, and the recognition of the rich stellar data available among the spectra of the main SDSS survey. In order to measure the dynamics of the halo of the Milky Way, SEGUE requires stellar radial velocities accurate to 10 km s<sup>−1</sup>, significantly more demanding than the original SDSS requirements of 30 km s<sup>−1</sup>. The previous version of <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> had systematic errors of 10–15 km s<sup>−1</sup> in the wavelength calibration because of a dearth of strong lines at the blue end of the spectrum in the calibration lamps and in the nighttime sky. The sky‐li

Under good conditions, a typical spectroscopic plate is observed three times in exposures of 15 minutes each; more exposures are added in poor conditions to reach a target S/N in the spectra. The <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> pipeline stitches together the resulting individual spectra to determine the final spectrum of a given object. However, for the most accurate determination of the noise characteristics of the spectra (for example, in detailed analyses of the Lyα forest of quasars; see th

There is a known problem, which is not fixed with the current version of <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace>, whereby the code that combines the individual 15 minute exposures will occasionally misinterpret the peaks of particularly strong and narrow emission lines as cosmic rays and remove them. Mask Design and Spectroscopy

Spectroscopic masks for each cluster were designed using object positions and colors from the photometric catalogs. The highest priority slits were manually placed on candidate lensed background sources as identified by color and morphology, and then the mask was filled in with lower priority slits placed on red-sequence-selected cluster members with rAB ⩽ 22.5 in the photometric catalogs. The SDSS spectra are classified as stars, galaxies, or quasars, and redshifts are determined with an automated routine. In measuring the nebular emission lines of galaxies, it is important to properly account for the galaxy continuum which is very rich in stellar absorption features. The <monospace>spectro1d</monospace> pipeline (Subbarao et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apjs385902r74">2002</xref>) used in DR7 performs a simple estimate of the continuum using a sliding median. The <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> code described in Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="apjs385902s4-2">4.2</xref> uses a PCA technique

In measuring the nebular emission lines of galaxies, it is important to properly account for the galaxy continuum which is very rich in stellar absorption features. The <monospace>spectro1d</monospace> pipeline (Subbarao et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apjs385902r74">2002</xref>) used in DR7 performs a simple estimate of the continuum using a sliding median. The <monospace>idlspec2d</monospace> code described in Section <xref ref-type="sec" rid="apjs385902s4-2">4.2</xref> uses a PCA technique

After subtracting the best-fitting stellar population model of the continuum, we remove any remaining residuals (usually of order a few percent) with a sliding 150 pixel median and fit all the nebular emission lines simultaneously as Gaussians. We describe the design and data analysis of the DEEP2 Galaxy Redshift Survey, the densest and largest high-precision redshift survey of galaxies at <italic>z</italic> ∼ 1 completed to date. The survey was designed to conduct a comprehensive census of massive galaxies, their properties, environments, and large-scale structure down to absolute magnitude <italic>M<sub>B</sub></italic> = −20 at <italic>z</italic> ∼ 1 via ∼90 nights of observation on the Keck telescope. The survey covers an ar

Sections <xref ref-type="sec" rid="apjs479035s9">9</xref> and <xref ref-type="sec" rid="apjs479035s10">10</xref> describe the spectroscopic exposures and their reduction, including detailed information on the <italic>spec2d</italic> pipeline that produces the reduced one-dimensional (1D) and two-dimensional (2D) spectra. This pipeline has been employed by many DEIMOS users; this paper provides its definitive description. The features of the DEIMOS spectrograph and <italic>spec2d</italic> pipelin

Sections <xref ref-type="sec" rid="apjs479035s9">9</xref> and <xref ref-type="sec" rid="apjs479035s10">10</xref> describe the spectroscopic exposures and their reduction, including detailed information on the <italic>spec2d</italic> pipeline that produces the reduced one-dimensional (1D) and two-dimensional (2D) spectra. This pipeline has been employed by many DEIMOS users; this paper provides its definitive description. The features of the DEIMOS spectrograph and <italic>spec2d</italic> pipelin

The DEIMOS <italic>spec2d</italic> pipeline (Cooper et al. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apjs479035r46">2012b</xref>) is an IDL-based code that is modeled on and borrows significant code from the SDSS spectral pipeline of David Schlegel and Scott Burles (Schlegel & Burles <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="apjs479035r134">2012</xref>). Most of it was written by Douglas Finkbeiner, Marc Davis, Jeffrey Newman, and Michael Cooper, with important contributions from Brian Gerke regarding non-local sky subtracti

The code is publicly available, and further information may be found about how it works and how to download it at <ext-link ext-link-type="url">http://deep.berkeley.edu/DR4</ext-link> and <ext-link ext-link-type="url">http://deep.berkeley.edu/spec2d/</ext-link>.

The output of the <italic>spec2d</italic> pipeline is a set of extracted spectra, one for each object. Obtaining redshifts and object classifications from these spectra is the task of a separate software pipeline, <italic>spec1d</italic>. This IDL code base inherits much from the SDSS <italic>specBS</italic> pipeline produced by David Schlegel, Scott Burles, and Douglas Finkbeiner, with modifications and new routines by Michael Cooper, Marc Davis, Darren Madgwick, Renbin Yan, and Jeffrey Newman.

The redshifts stored in a <italic>zspec</italic> file are first compared to those provided in the corresponding mask's <italic>zresult</italic> file (i.e., the original output from the <italic>spec1d</italic> redshift pipeline), which contains information on 10 candidate redshifts, selected based on reduced χ<sup>2</sup>, for each object. For all objects to which the <italic>zspec</italic> user assigned redshift quality code <italic>Q</italic> = 3 or 4 (i.e., obtained a secure redshift me

A similar test is shown in Figure <xref ref-type="fig" rid="apjs479035f35">35</xref>, which compares errors for red and blue galaxies rather than dividing up objects according to their quality codes (though blue, emission-line galaxies predominantly yield <italic>Q</italic> = 4 redshifts, with a greater <italic>Q</italic> = 3 fraction for red galaxies). By adding an extra 17 km s<sup>−1</sup> error in quadrature for blue galaxies, or 32 km s<sup>−1</sup> for red galaxies, we can ma

The spectra taken by the BOSS spectrograph were processed with the latest BOSS spectroscopic pipeline <italic>idlspec2d</italic> v5_7_1, which performs flat-fielding, one-dimensional (1D) extraction, wavelength calibration, sky subtraction, and flux calibration using flat fields, arcs, F-star, and sky fiber spectra. The details of the pipeline are described in D. Schlegel et al. (2015, in preparation). The individual sub-exposures are coadded for each epoch (plugging) with a logarithmic waveleng

In the RM data products, we will provide the recalibrated spectra (<monospace>spPlate*</monospace> files) with and without the Wild & Hewett sky subtraction. In addition to the individual epochs, we will also provide the final coadded spectra using all epochs, generated using <italic>idlspec2d</italic>. The coadded spectra are organized in the same way as individual epochs, with an assigned plate number of 0000 and an MJD corresponding to the last coadded epoch; fibers 1–1000 in the coadded plat

As in previous BOSS data releases, a unique tag of the idlspec2d spectroscopic pipeline software is associated with each unique sample of publicly released data.142

SDSS data processing software is publicly available at http://www.sdss.org/dr12/software/products/

The SDSS-RM project provides a unique opportunity to study data-quality biases in the measurement of spectroscopic properties of quasars from survey spectra. Each epoch is representative of a typical survey-quality spectrum, although the reader should note that the exposure time of our SE spectra is greater than a typical SDSS or BOSS quasar spectrum, with a 2 hr rather than the minimum 45-minute exposure. Trimmed_XML_tag1_content: It is generally suggested that the <monospace>macroatom</monospace> TARDIS mode for line treatment is used instead of the <monospace>downbranch</monospace> mode that we employ, since the former provides a more physical approximation. Specifically, the <monospace>macroatom</monospace> approximation better describes de-excitation cascades (and multiple-photon excitation, though those are less likely to be important) than does the simpler <monospace>downbranch</monospace> mode. Nevertheless, we ret
Trimmed_XML_tag2_content:
Modeling Uncertainties

An important limitation of our analysis follows from the approximation of the incoming radiation field from the pseudo-photosphere as blackbody radiation. This approximation becomes progressively worse starting about a week after maximum, as the ejecta evolve and the photosphere moves in too far. For comparison with previous work, we nevertheless included some simulations at such late epochs.

INTRODUCTION

The dispersive nature of the plasma that pervades interstellar and intergalactic space causes the observed arrival time of impulsive astrophysical radio signals to be strongly frequency dependent. In cold plasmas the dispersive delay is proportional to λ2 DM, where the dispersion measure, DM, is the line-of-sight electron column density. The effects of dispersion are particularly manifest in searches for pulsars and short-timescale trans

We used <italic>imwcs</italic> in WCSTools (Mink <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="rf51">1999</xref>), version 2.7.2, for the astrometric solutions. There were 36 sources detected in one or two of the VLT filters, but not all three. This usually occurred when the source was highly obscured and no <italic>H</italic>‐ and/or <italic>J</italic>‐band detection was made. Photometry was performed using the <italic>SExtractor</italic> package (Bertin & Arnouts <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="aj332189r10">1996</xref>) with a 3σ source-detection limit. Trimmed_XML_tag2_content:
CCD Orientation

The proper motions derived above are in the approximate (R.A., decl.) directions given by the orientation of the corresponding SFR, which do not necessarily coincide with the Equatorial System for a given Equinox. To evaluate/correct for this possible effect, we have to find the orientation of the SFRs with respect to the International Celestial Reference frame (ICRF; Arias et al. 1995).

The size of each association was estimated by determining the spatial extent of the FWHM of the flux density profile of stars. Specifically, stars/sources were counted in radial bins from the association center, the fluxes from sources in each bin were totaled, and the standard deviation of the spatial flux density distribution was computed. SUPRIME-CAM FLUX CALIBRATION USING SDSS

We took special care with the flux calibration. The B-band of the Suprime-Cam has different transmission from the standard Johnson–B because of the low throughput of CCDs at shorter wavelengths. In addition, the R-band of the Suprime-Cam has different transmission from Kron–Cousins–R as it has a much shallower range.

Trimmed_XML_tag2_content:
Near- and Mid-infrared Photometry

Prior to the launch of Spitzer, several of our intended targets were known to be multiple sources while others had yet to be checked for multiplicity. To determine the contribution of any potential companion to our future spectra at IRS wavelengths, we imaged these targets at 2.2, 4.68, 11.7, and 20.8 μm.

Observing Strategy

Each Cepheid was observed an average of 22 epochs in the J, H, and K filters. The exposure times varied for each Cepheid based on the Cepheid brightness and the sky background. Astrometric and Photometric Calibration

We determined the astrometric solution of our master reference image based on an independent astrometric calibration of a single frame (15CC0007) obtained during the same observing season by M. Ashley (2008, private communication). We found 5300 stars in common between this frame and our master reference image using DAOMATCH and DAOMASTER (developed by P. Stetson). A master star catalog was created from the 15 individual photometry lists (five epochs, three wavelengths each) using DAOMATCH and DAOMASTER. DAOMATCH and DAOMASTER are separate programs that merge photometry output files from DAOphot into a single file with matched point sources. DAOMATCH finds the translation, rotation, and scaling solution between the photometry files, and DAOMASTER then matches point sources by pixel coordinates.
